msIdentifier.repository: Peterborough Cathedral Library: on long-term deposit at Cambridge University Library

msDesc.head: Cartulary of Peterborough Abbey (The Book of Robert of Swaffham)

summary.seg: The monastery of Peterborough was first founded in the seventh century as 'Medeshamstede'; after its destruction by the Danes, it was refounded in the tenth century as 'Burgh' (Peterborough). In the mid-thirteenth century it had an establishment of 80 monks. One of them, Robert of Swaffham, gave his name to this substantial volume, indicating that it was compiled by him or under his auspices. The text in the main hand can be dated to the abbacy of John of Caux (reg. 1249-1263), and there are later additions up to the fourteenth century. The book remained in the cathedral library after the Dissolution, but it came close to being lost in the seventeenth century civil war, after being found by one of Cromwell's soldiers when they ransacked the cathedral in 1643. The master of the choristers, Humfrey Austin, purchased it from him for 10s, claiming that it was 'an old Latin bible', and his receipt for this sum is copied on the flyleaf of the manuscript. It then remained safely in the library of the Dean and Chapter until it was transferred to Cambridge in 1980.

The book was the monastery's first complete cartulary, and the first point of reference not just for the monks but thereafter for the learned clergy of the cathedral, including Simon Gunton (bap. 1609, d. 1676) and White Kennett (1660-1728). It bears signs of heavy use. There are frequent marginal annotations, including cross-references to later material, and numerous cloth and parchment page markers attached for ease of reference. One of these takes readers to Henry III's reissue of Magna Carta in 1225.

The cartulary starts with a list of contents, with references to the folio numbers. It then contains the house chronicle, compiled by the monk Hugh Candidus in the mid-twelfth century and here continued to the death of Abbot Walter of St Edmunds in 1245 by Robert of Swaffham. There follow royal and papal charters, each section starting with forgeries relating to the first foundation at Medeshamstede; after which come charters of the abbots, including endowments to the convent to commemorate their anniversaries.

Thereafter, around half way through the text, the structure becomes more amorphous. Surveys of the abbey's demesne manors, made in the twelfth and thirteenth centuries, are clearly intended to preface the main section of grants of grants of land and privileges to the monastery and to individual departments. There is a small group of documents relating to the knightly tenancies of the abbey. Finally, in the original hand, is the earliest surviving copy of the Gesta Herewardi, which had been written at Ely a century earlier, and which deals with the exploits of Hereward 'the Wake' in the aftermath of the Conquest. It provides an element of romance at the end of this highly utilitarian compilation.
An edition of the cartulary is being prepared by Dr Nicholas Karn, to be published by the Northamptonshire Record Society under the auspices of the Anthony Mellows Memorial Trust.

Edmund King
Emeritus Professor of Medieval History
University of Sheffield

seg.hi: Conservation and digitisation of the manuscript

summary.seg: In 2024, thanks to a generous gift from Edmund King, the Book of Robert of Swaffham was conserved, digitised and rebound. The conservation and rebinding work was undertaken by Shaun Thompson, of the Library's Conservation and Collection Care Department.

msContents.textLang: Latin, with some Old French and Middle English

msItem.note: See Provenance for further details.

msItem.title: Extract from the Valuation of Norwich
Extracts concerning the rights and dues of Peterborough Abbey

msItem.incipit: 3r: Dominus Stephanus domini capellis ante pasca venit in angliam
msItem.explicit: 3r: duabus marcis quietum adiudicauerunt
msItem.note: Title taken from marginal annotation.

msItem.incipit: 3r: Rex transiuit in britanniam vigilia apostolorum
msItem.explicit: 3r: in eorum rotuli continetur et in ferius scriptus est
msItem.note: Title taken from marginal annotation.

msItem.title: Milites honoris Burgi
msItem.incipit: 3r: In tempore eiusdem abbatis . a . iuerunt magnis sumptibus
msItem.explicit: 3r: et quare breve fuit besiliatis abbas perdidit tunc scutagium
msItem.note: Title taken from marginal annotation. 'Henricus rex iii' in the margin.

msItem.title: Historical notes on the reigns of English kings, from Alfred to Henry II
msItem.incipit: 4r: Rex sapientissimus Alfredus litterali et seculari
msItem.explicit: 4r: in tronum regni splendidissime collocatus

msItem.title: Table of contents
msItem.note: 'List of contents, written rather later than the main text, and including many, but not all, of the later additions, and occasionally some of the marginal notes' (Martin (1978), p. 9)
Entries are keyed to the medieval foliation, in Roman numerals, written here in red.

msItem.title: Prologue
msItem.rubric: 17r | i recto: Prologus subsequentis narracionis
msItem.incipit: 17r | i recto: Scripturus de loco quiquondam medeshamstede

msItem.title: Text
msItem.rubric: 17r | i recto: Narracio fundamenti et destruccionis et restauracionis ecclesie sancti Petri de Burgo et ipsius fundatorum et restauratorum
msItem.incipit: 17r | i recto: Est nobile monasterium in regione gyruiroum
msItem.explicit: 35r | xix recto: accusatus anno uicesimo uno primo prelacionis eius depositus est
msItem.note: The last four words are written by a slightly later hand.
Accompanied by marginal chronology and notes, by a later hand.

msItem.title: Continuation of the Chronicle of Hugh Candidus
msItem.author: Robert of Swaffham
msItem.incipit: 35v | xix verso: Uenerabilis Abbas Burgi Benedictus ecclesie christi Cantuarie prior extitit
msItem.explicit: 42r | xxvi recto: Quatuor cultelli mensales
msItem.note: Continues the narrative from 1177 to 1246, copied by a different hand (Ker (1992), p. 163).

msItem.title: List of books copied for Abbot Benedict (reg. 1177-1193)
msItem.incipit: 35v | xix verso: Uetus et nouum testamentum in uno uolumine
msItem.explicit: 36r | xx recto: Libellus de compoto

msItem.title: Copies of charters and other documents (1260-1275)
msItem.note: '[I]n various later hands, filling in the blank leaves. The majority are in the list of contents, though not in sequence (at ff. 6v, 12v, 13r, 13v); those dated fall into the period 1260-1275' (Martin (1978), p. 9)

msItem.title: Royal charters (Wulfhere to Henry III)
msItem.note: 'From Wulfhere (664) to Henry III, but beginning with the Relacio Hedde Abbatis (printed in Dugdale [...]); not all relate specifically to Peterborough, e.g. Henry III's confirmation of Magna Carta, 1225, at f. 61r | xlv recto. The original section ended with the Statute of Merton, 1236' (Martin (1978), p. 9).

Repeated in Peterborough Cathedral, MS 5, ff. 39r | xxiii recto-56r | xl recto. 'The section ends (ff. 71v | lvi verso-80r | lxv recto) with Magna Carta of John, Charter of the Forest of Henry III, Magna Carta of 1235, 'Sentencia data per B. Cant' Archiepiscopum et xiij suffraganeos suos', and Provisions of Merton' (Ker (1992), p. 163)

msItem.title: The Relatio Hedde Abbatis
msItem.incipit: 53r | xxxvii recto: Relatio Hedde abbatis quomodo incipiente christianitate in regione mediterraneorum anglorum
msItem.explicit: 53v | xxxvii verso: subtractis aliquibus uersibus causa breuiandi hic inseruntur

msItem.title: Grant by Wulfhere, 664
msItem.rubric: 53v | xxxvii verso: Carta Wlferi Regis de eodem
msItem.incipit: 53v | xxxvii verso: Uulfere dei beneficio rex merciorum et mediterraneourum anglorum
msItem.explicit: 54v | xxxviii verso: nullius insana et punienda cupiditas uiolet
msItem.note: Wulfhere, king of the Mercians and the Middle Angles, confirms and grants land to St Peter's, Medeshamstede, 664 (Kelly).

listBibl.bibl: Kelly (2009), no. 1, pp. 131-44 [with additional references and commentary]

msItem.title: Grant by Edgar, 972, and subsequent confirmations
msItem.rubric: 54v | xxxviii verso: Carta Regis Edgari
msItem.incipit: 54v | xxxviii verso: Gracia domini nostri ihesu christi . Regis omnium seculorum omnia suo nutu distribuentis
msItem.explicit: 56r | xl recto: Willelmus Maleit . Ingeluus Presbiter
msItem.note: King Edgar grants the freedom of the minster formerly called Medeshamstede but now called Burch (Peterborough), with its appurtenances at Dogsthorpe, Eye and Paston; and also grants the same freedom to the estate at Oundle, Northamptonshire, with its eight dependant hundreds; and to the minster's lands at Barrow-upon-Humber, Lincolnshire; and Warmington, Ashton, Kettering, Castor, Ailsworth, Walton, Werrington, Eye and Thorpe, Northamptonshire; together with one moneyer in Stamford, half of Whittlesey Mere, control over the Peterborough market and extensive toll-privileges, 972 (Kelly).

listBibl.bibl: Kelly (2009), no. 16, pp. 258-71 [with additional references and commentary]

msItem.note: Later additions.

msItem.title: Charters
msItem.note: Later additions.

msItem.title: Division of England into kingdoms, counties and bishoprics

msItem.note: Later additions.

msItem.note: From London, Society of Antiquaries, MS 60, f. 228v.

msItem.title: Treatise on weights and measures

msItem.note: Later additions, with additional commentary on f. 86r | lxxi recto. For an explanation, see: A.S.C. Ross, 'The assize of bread', Economic History Review, new ser. 9 (1956), 332-342.

msItem.title: Papal privileges
msItem.note: Begins with the spurious bull of Pope Agatho, 680; ends with Innocent IV, 1249.

msItem.title: Privilege of Pope Agatho
msItem.rubric: 88r | lxxiii recto: Priuilegium Agathonis [pape] in prima fundacione ecclesie Burgi

msItem.explicit: 89r | lxxiv recto: in pace custodiat dei gracias
msItem.note: In the rubric, 'pape' has been erased.

listBibl.bibl: Kelly (2009), no. 2, pp. 160-70 [with additional references and commentary]

msItem.title: Privilege of Pope Agatho
msItem.incipit: 92r | lxxvii recto: Gloriosissimo filio regi merciorum Ethelredo . fratribus quoque et coepiscopus theodoro
msItem.explicit: 92v | lxxvii verso: sit abomini seruitutue seculari libera

listBibl.bibl: Kelly (2009), no. 2, pp. 160-70 [with additional references and commentary]

msItem.title: Privilege of Pope Constantine for HÃ¦dda, Abbot of Bermondsey and Woking [708Ã715]
msItem.rubric: 101r | lxxxvi recto: Constantini pape de Wermundeshey et Wookinges
msItem.incipit: 101r | lxxxvi recto: Constantinus Episcopus sruus seruoroum dei hedda religioso
msItem.explicit: 101v | lxxxvi verso: canonicis animaduersionibus subiacebit . Bene valete
msItem.note: 'pape' erased in the rubric.

listBibl.bibl: Kelly (2009), Appendix 2 [with additional references and commentary]

msItem.title: Charters of archbishops and bishops
msItem.note:
Begins with Theobald, archbishop of Canterbury, and includes agreements with other religious houses and some charters issued by the abbots of Peterborough, especially to the obedientiaries. From f. 115v | c verso, they are arranged under abbots:
f. 115v | c verso, William of Waterville
f. 117r | cii recto, Andrew
f. 117v | cii verso, Acharius
f. 119v | civ verso, Robert of Lindsey
f. 121r | cvi recto, Alexander of Holderness, Martin of Ramsey
f. 121v | cvi verso, Walter of St Edmunds
f. 122r | cvii recto, William Hotot
f. 123r | cviii recto, John of Caux

msItem.title: Royal grants of land, etc
msItem.note: General grants to the abbey and other documents relating to the estates, including extracts from Domesday Book at f. 137v | cxxii verso and the Northamptonshire Survey at f. 139r | cxxiv recto (see: Henry of Pytchley's Book of Fees, ed. by W.T. Mellows, Publications of the Northamptonshire Record Society 2 ([Northampton]: Northamptonshire Record Society, 1927), p. xxxviii; and VCH Northants, 1, pp. 357-89 (ed. by J.H. Round)).

msItem.title: Confirmation by Edward [1061Ã1066]
msItem.rubric: 124r | cix recto: Sancti Edwardi Regis de Scotton, Scotere et Malmetun'
msItem.incipit: 124r | cix recto: Cum uniuersorum dominus et iudex dicit
msItem.explicit: 124r | cix recto: quicumque sancto petro prescriptas terras abstulerit
msItem.note: Kind Edward confirms land at Scotton, Scotter and Manton, Lincolnshire, to Peterborough [1061Ã1066] (Kelly).

listBibl.bibl: Kelly (2009), no. 24, pp. 306-08 [with additional references and commentary]

msItem.title: Confirmation by Edward [1055Ã1060], with additional passage
msItem.rubric: 124r | cix recto: Eiusdem Edwardi Regis de . vii . carucatis terre in Walcote et una in Alchebarwe et ecclesia et in Normanneby . i . et in aletorp dimidiam et in Muscum . i . et . ii . bouates
msItem.incipit: 124r | cix recto: Propeter breuitatem et uarias mutaciones mortalium
msItem.explicit: 124v | cix verso: Ego elfnothus minister
msItem.note: King Edward confirm land at Walcot in Alkborough, Lincolnshire, given to Peterborough by Askytel, the king's optimas [1055Ã1060]; with additional passage in this manuscript and Peterborough Cathedral, MS 5, referring to land in Walcot, Alkborough, Normanby, Althorpe, Lincolnshire; and Muskham, Nottinghamshire (Kelly).

listBibl.bibl: Kelly (2009), no. 22, pp. 298-302 [with additional references and commentary]

msItem.title: Confirmation by Edward, 1060
msItem.rubric: 126r | cxi recto: Regis Eduuardi de villa de Fiskerton'
msItem.incipit: 126r | cxi recto: Oportet nos quos deus prefecit temporaliter rectores populo
msItem.explicit: 126v | cxi verso: signum laulf Maltesune
msItem.note: King Edward confirms the land at Fiskerton, Lincolnshire, bequeathed to Peterborough by Leofgifu of London, 1060 (Kelly).

listBibl.bibl: Kelly (2009), no. 23, pp. 302-06 [with additional references and commentary]

msItem.title: Grant by Edgar, 971
msItem.rubric: 126v | cxi verso: Edgarii Regis de Baruue
msItem.incipit: 126v | cxi verso: Uniuersitatis sophie studium intento mentis conamine
msItem.explicit: 126v | cxi verso: hiis metis prefatum rus hinc inde giratur
msItem.note: King Edgar grants land at Barrow-upon-Humber, Lincolnshire, to Bishop Ãthelwold, for Peterborough Abbey, 971 (Kelly).

listBibl.bibl: Kelly (2009), no. 15, pp. 247-57 [with additional references and commentary]

msItem.title: Grant by CÃ¦dwalla [probably 686Ã687] and subsequent confirmations
msItem.rubric: 126v | cxi verso: Cedwalle Regis de . xl . manentibus in Hogh
msItem.incipit: 126v | cxi verso: In nomine tocius christi creature recuperatoris . cum igitur dominus secularia
msItem.explicit: 127v | cxii verso: Ego helmulfus consensi . et subscripti
msItem.note: CÃ¦dwalla, king [of the West Saxons], grants forty hides (manentes) at Hoo, Kent, to Abbot Ecgbald and his familia [probably 686Ã687]; Sighere, king of the [East] Saxons, confirms this grant [c. 687]; SwÃ¦fheard, king [of Kent], confirms this grant and gives a further twenty hides at Hoo and woodland at Fercanhamstede to Abbot Ecgbald [(1 March 687Ã28 February 688) Ã (July 692Ã694), probably c. 691]; Wihtred, king [of Kent], confirms this grant [probably c. 691]; and Confirmation by Ãthelred, king of the Mercians [probably c. 691] (Kelly).

listBibl.bibl: Kelly (2009), no. 5, pp. 186-98 [with additional references and commentary]

msItem.title: Narrative records of lawsuits and property transactions (early 12th century)
msItem.note: Discussed, and some translated, in King, Peterborough Abbey, pp. 27-34 and Van Caenegem, English Lawsuits, vol. 1, nos. 214, 220 (from Peterborough MS 5).

msItem.title: Acquisition by Ãlfsige [1020Ã1023], and description of them
msItem.rubric: 134v | cxix verso: Empcio Ãlfy Abbatis de . iiii . parte de Witlesmere . ad aliam terciam partem
msItem.incipit: 134v | cxix verso: Hic comprobatur quod Alfi Abbas de Burch
msItem.explicit: 135r | cxx recto: occidentalis paludum et aquarum de Witlesmere pertinentium
msItem.note: Ãlfsige, abbot of Peterborough, acquires fenland at Whittlesey Mere from Thored, in exchange for land at Orton, Huntingdonshire, and a sum of money [1020Ã1023]; description of Peterborough holdings in Whittlesey Mere (Kelly).

listBibl.bibl: Kelly (2009), no. 20, pp. 287-94 [with additional references and commentary]

msItem.title: Description of forest at Nassaburgh
msItem.incipit: 135v | cxx verso: Hec est descripcio boscorum de Nasso Burgi que facta fuit in disaforestacione
msItem.explicit: 136v | cxxi verso: et de Rifleto viginti quatuor acras
msItem.note: 'Four knights and a clerk surveyed the woodland, and this document is the result of their survey. It lists the names of the woods and their extent, together with the names of their owners. Eighty-four pieces of woodland are listed here, amounting to slightly under 1600 acres' (King).
See also ff. 136r | cxxi recto, 257r | ccxliii recto, 257r | ccxliii recto-257v | ccxliii verso.

msItem.title: Agreement on assarting
msItem.rubric: 136r | cxxi recto: Inter abbatem et conuentum burgi et milites et francolanos de nasso burgi de boscis et refletis suis
msItem.incipit: 136r | cxxi recto: Sciant omnes tam presentes quam futuri quod hec est conuencio facta
msItem.explicit: 136r | cxxi recto: et monachorum uel aliquorum vicinorum suorum
msItem.note: Written in the margin.

'The abbot and convent on the one hand and the knights and freeholders on the other come to an agreement concerning assarting in their respective woodland. The chief problem here concerned rights of common. This comprehensive agreement comes a generation before the Statute of Merton, and anticipates several of its provisions. It is notable also in being sealed by six knights, as representatives of the local community' (King).
See also ff. 135v | cxx verso-136v | cxxi verso, 257r | ccxliii recto, 257r | ccxliii recto-257v | ccxliii verso.

msItem.title: List of benefactors of Peterborough
msItem.rubric: 136v | cxxi verso: Prologus sequentis scripta
msItem.incipit: 136v | cxxi verso: In hac breui cartula continentur eorum nomina qui terras et possessiones suas
msItem.rubric: 136v | cxxi verso: Nomina eorum qui terras et tenementa deder' sancto Petro in Burch
msItem.incipit: 136v | cxxi verso: Lefuuinus princepts Elfuuini filius dedit Aluuoltum
msItem.explicit: 137r | cxxii recto: In Muskam vnam Carutatem et duas bouetas
msItem.note: From London, Society of Antiquaries, MS 60, f. 71v.

listBibl.bibl: Kelly (2009), no. 31, pp. 346-57 [with additional references and commentary]

msItem.explicit: 137v | cxxii verso: Rieygenaldtorp tres carucatas in Dominio

msItem.incipit: 139v | cxxiv verso: Uniuersis sophie studium intento mentis conamine sedulo rimantibus
msItem.explicit: 140r | cxxv recto: Ego Ulf . Offerd' Ç·ulfÈeat

King Edgar grants land at Howden and Drax, Yorkshire, to Quen, matrona, 959 (Kelly).

msItem.title: Grant by CÃ¦dwalla [probably 686Ã687] and subsequent confirmations
msItem.incipit: 144v | cxxix verso: In nomine christi tocius creature recuperatoris . cum igitur dominus secularia

msItem.note: Begins with the sacrist; from f. 196r | clxxxii recto, many relate to the chamberlain; from f. 198r | clxxxiv recto, to various altars in the church; and from f. 202r | clxxxviii recto, to the infirmary. Continued by later hands on ff. 202v | clxxxviii verso-206v | cxcii verso.

msItem.title: General deeds
msItem.note: No indication in the list of contents as to category. At the beginning, some relate to the London properties, and some to the sacristy (e.g. at f. 220v | ccvi verso). Others appear to be in groups concerning one man e.g. Ralph, son of Martin de Maxey at f. 230v | ccxvi verso, and Hugh Fluri at f. 235r | ccxxi recto). Folios 262r | ccxlviii recto-276r | cclxii recto are almonry charters, and a later hand has added 'ad elemmosinariam' to many of the headings. Continued by later hands on ff. 276v | cclxii verso-278v | cclxiv verso.

extent.seg: iv + 9 + 382 + 13 + iv leaves. The manuscript contains perhaps three sets of medieval endleaves, an accretion that reflects successive rebindings (see Binding for further details).

foliation.note: This manuscript contains two main foliation sequences, one medieval and one 17th-century (both written in ink), the latter of which is continued by a 20th-century hand writing in pencil. They overlap with one another, but neither on its own provides comprehensive coverage of all of the medieval leaves in the volume. Standard practice at Cambridge University Library would ordinarily be to follow the foliation in pencil, and supply numbering for other unfoliated medieval and modern endleaves using Roman numerals and lower case letters, in square brackets. However, most scholarship on this manuscript has referred to its contents according to the medieval foliation sequence in lower case Roman numerals. For this reason, it has been decided to provide both foliation sequences in the image labelling and in the folio references in this description.

Folios 1-140 numbered in ink in the upper-right hand corner of the recto side of each leaf, by a 17th-century hand. '63' was repeated in error; the second of these leaves has been designated [63a] for the purposes of this description. The sequence was continued from 141 to 383 by a 20th-century hand, writing in pencil in the same location.

foliation.p: i-clxviii, clxx-cccxi, cccvi, cccxvii, cccviii, cccxix-cccxlvi, cccvii, cccxlviii-ccclviii, ccclx-ccclxxii (for ff. 17-381)
foliation.note: Written in ink in the middle of the upper margin of the recto side of each leaf by a mid-13th-century hand (with occasional corrections by later hands). Tables of contents at the front and back of the manuscript are keyed to this sequence, confirming that it was added at an early stage in the manuscript's history, probably contemporary with its production.

Folios cccvi and cccviii should properly have been foliated as 'cccxvi' and 'cccxviii', and folio cccvii likewise should have been 'cccxlvii', and all three are shown as such in the folio references for this description.

list.item: Quire 1812-1 (ff. 184 | clxx-194 | clxxx: 1st leaf missing, before f. 184 | clxx)
Quire 2810-2 (ff. 303 | cclxxxix-310 | ccxcvi: 7th and 8th leaves cancelled, after f. 308 | ccxciv)
Quire 3012-5 (ff. 323 | cccix-329 | cccxix: 1st leaf cancelled, before f. 323 | cccix; 5th-8th leaves, after f. 325 | cccxi, removed, probably blank)
Quire 3512-1 (ff. 366 | ccclvi-376 | ccclxvii: 4th leaf excised, probably blank (aside from foliation), after f. 369 | ccclx)
Quire 366-1 (ff. 377 | ccclxviii-381 | ccclxxii: 4th leaf not present/?excised, after f. 379 | ccclxx)

p.formula: 14 28 34 4-1712 1812-1 19-2712 2810-2 (7th-8th cancelled) 2912 3012-5 3112 (1st cancelled; 5th-8th removed) 328 334 3412 3512-1 (4th excised) Quire 366-1 (4th not present/?excised)

signatures.p:
Leaf signatures mostly absent, with only occasional sequences of various sorts, written in plummet in the lower margin:
minuscule letters (Q10; ff. 88 | lxxiii-91 | lxxvi only)
O, with the number denoted by horizontal bars above (Q11, 16 [partly cropped], 20)
minuscule letter, with Roman numerals (Q14 = b; Q15 = a; Q17 = d; Q19 = f; Q21 = e; Q27, 29 and 31 = numerals only)

Two sets of quire signatures:
13th-century: Quires 4-24 signed 'i-xxi' (ff. 17r | i recto-266v | cclii verso), written in the centre of the lower margin of the first recto of each quire
14th-century: Quires 4-32 signed 'i-xxix' (ff. 17r | i recto-349v | cccxxxix verso), written at various positions in the lower margin of the first recto and last verso of each quire
The longer sequence of 14th-century quire signatures does not signal the addition of extra quires at this point. They may have been added in preparation for the rebinding of the manuscript.

catchwords.seg: Catchwords by a 13th-century hand occasionally visible and often partly cropped (see, for example, ff. 28v | xii verso, 63v | xlvii verso), supplanted by additions by a 14th-century hand, apparently the same as that responsible for the quire signatures (and likewise perhaps in preparation for rebinding).

supportDesc.condition: Evidence of re-agent use on ff. 278v | cclxiv verso, 289r | cclxxv recto.

layout.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame and line. Single columns, 35 lines to the page, written below top line. Number of lines and written space outside the core 13th-century production is more variable.

handNote.p: The core 13th-century production was written by several hands in littera textualis of varying formality, the principal contributor presumably being either Robert of Swaffham (fl. c. 1250-1271)Robert, of Swaffham, -1273? or someone working at his direction (see Origin for further details). The prefatory tables of contents and many early additions are in charter script, again by multiple hands.

Later additions by numerous hands, writing variously in anglicana (e.g. ff. 45r | xxix recto-47r | xxxi recto, 81r | lxvi recto-82r | lxvii recto, 86r | lxxi recto, 282r | cclxviii recto-282v | cclxviii verso, 299r | cclxxxv recto-300r | cclxxxvi recto, 304r | ccxc recto-305r | ccxci recto, 308v | ccxciv verso-309r | ccxcv recto, 328r | cccxviii recto-328v | cccxviii verso and 354r | cccxliv recto - all early to mid-14th century; 355v | cccxlv verso-364r | cccliv recto - later 14th- and some 15th-century).

decoNote.p: Four-line initial in blue with red and blue infill and marginal flourishing (f. 17r | i recto) and two-line versions, alternating as above or in red with blue infill and flourishing, at intervals throughout the text. Differences in style and proportion indicate their execution by several hands, all of the 13th century.
Litterae notabiliores in the text touched with red.
Occasional sketches of faces in the margins, in plummet (e.g. ff. 146v | cxxxi verso, 152r | cxxxvii recto).

note.p: Numerous marginal additions and content-markers, by hands of the 13th-15th centuries, as well as further annotations by 16th- and 17th-century hands, throughout the manuscript.

binding.p: Full alum-tawed calfskin over oak boards, new parchment endleaves, quires on original sewing stations, by Shaun ThompsonThompson, Shaun of the Conservation and Collection Care Department, Cambridge University Library, 2024.

A post-medieval binding of possibly the ?16th century (Ker) or ?17th century (Shaun Thompson, personal communication) was applied to the manuscript, comprising wooden boards (perhaps recycled from the binding of this or another manuscript), covered with brown tanned calfskin, over which a 15th-century cover of blind-tooled leather (now abraded and torn) was applied. Two catches (of which only one survives). The spine was reinforced later, comprising a tawed leather cover or bonnet for the spine and metal-alloy plates (or 'sliders') along the joints holding it in place.

This binding and other materials collected during the conservation process have been retained and are stored with the manuscript. Images of these are placed at the end of the digital facsimile and show the following:
Images 835-836: Parchment patch liners
Images 837-838: Rehitching material used in reattaching gatherings to the text-block (top left); plant-based material, possibly including page-markers (top right); rehitching material (bottom left); and tail-ends of tanned skin slips removed from the board holes (bottom right)
Images 839-840: Heavy sewing supports formed of tanned skin, with attached abbreviated sewing thread
Images 841-842: Remains of the abbreviated sewing thread (top); and detritus collected from the leaves of the manuscript during conservation cleaning (bottom)
Images 843-844: Endband cores (top left); red and blue endband tie-downs from a previous endband (?medieval); a seed pod and fragment of pigment (middle left); and ?nib of a feathered pen, in two pieces
Images 845-846: A medieval decorated hooked catch of metal alloy, from the lower of two clasps, formerly attached to the rear board
The manuscript contains perhaps three sets of medieval endleaves, an accretion that reflects successive rebindings during the medieval period.

The first sets of endleaves appear to have been formed of gatherings of four leaves at the front (now ff. 1-4) and six leaves at the back (now ff. 377-381), of which the first and the last respectively were used as pastedowns. Damage to the lower edge of ff. 1-3 indicates the presence of a chain staple - but the fact that friction holes or rust stains have not transmitted to adjoining endleaves suggests that the manuscript was not chained again after this first binding was removed.

When the manuscript was rebound, these pastedowns were lifted and bifolia added at the front (now ff. [viii]-[ix]) and the back (now ff. 382-383), again with the first and last leaves respectively serving as pastedowns.

The manuscript was bound a third time, at which juncture the pastedowns were once again lifted. That these rebindings took place during the medieval period is evinced by the presence of notes by late 14th-/early 15th-century hands on ff. [viii] recto and 383v, which were only accessible once they had been lifted. The notes on f. 383v concern the reigns of abbots of Peterborough, with the final name, Henry of Morcott, providing a terminus ante quem non for the third rebinding of 1353. At this third rebinding, more leaves were added on either side of the volume: at the front, two gatherings of four leaves (now ff. [i]-[vii]), and at the rear, three gatherings of four leaves (now ff. [x]-[xx]). Some losses had occurred at that point or later: the first leaf of the first gathering at the front (before f. [i]) and the second leaf of the gathering at the back (after f. [xviii]). Again, the first and last leaves in these groups respectively (f. [i] and [xx]) were pasted down.

A decorated hooked catch, not contemporary with the production of the manuscript, but certainly medieval and probably itself recycled from a larger manuscript, was reused in one of the later medieval rebindings of the manuscript and subsequently retained and reused as part of the ?16th/?17th-century binding (see above for further details).

origin.p: 'Liber Roberti de Swapham . de prima fundacione Burgensis Ecclesie et de Destructione et Restauracione eiusdem et de Priuilegiis et Cartis et omnibus libertatibus et Immunitatibus Eiusdem Ecclesie': Robert of Swaffham (fl. c. 1250-1271)Robert, of Swaffham, -1273? was the compiler of this cartulary, which was presumably written by him or someone working at his direction. Few details of Robert's life survive. He is recorded as the Abbey's pittancer in 1269 and its cellarer at Easter 1271. He is thought to have died shortly thereafter.

provenance.p: Owned by Peterborough AbbeyPeterborough Abbey from the manuscript's creation until the Dissolution. It was recorded as 'le Swaffam', in reference to its compiler (see Origin), in the Register of Richard Ashton, abbot 1438-1471 (which now comprises the first part of Peterborough Cathedral, MS 2, the 'Book of Roger Bird'). Thereupon, it remained in the possession of Peterborough CathedralPeterborough Cathedral until the Civil War (see below).

[ii] recto: 'The Coppie of his account', presumably written by the hand of Humfrey Austin, relating the hiding and discovery of the manuscript during the Civil War, and its recovery into the possession of Peterborough CathedralPeterborough Cathedral. 'This Booke was hide in the Church, by me Humfrey Austin; February 1642. And found by one of Coll: Cromwelle Souldgers when thay pul'd downe all ye seats in the Quire, April 22th 1643. And I makeing inquire a mongst them, for an Old Latin Bible which were lost, I found out at last ye partie who had it, and I gave him for ye booke Tenn shillings, as you see by this acq:'. And, beneath that: 'I pray let this Scripture booke alone for he hath paid me for it; therefore I would desire you to let it a lone; By me Henry Topclyffe, Souldger under Capt. Cromwell, Coll: Cromw. sonn; theirfore I praye let it a lone, By me Henry Topclyffe.'

history.acquisition: The manuscript was placed on deposit at Cambridge University Library between 1980 and 1983 and remains in possession of the Dean and Chapter of Peterborough Cathedral.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on the description provided by N.R. Ker and A.J. Piper, Medieval Manuscripts in British Libraries (Oxford, 1969-2002), 5 vols, IV: Paisley-York (1992), pp. 162-64, and in particular for the description of the contents on J. Martin, The cartularies and registers of Peterborough Abbey ([Northampton], 1978) and T.D. Hardy and C.T. Martin, Lestoire des Engles, Rolls Series 91 (London, 1888), pp. xlvii-lii.

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

custodialHist.custEvent: The manuscript was conserved and rebound in 2024 by Shaun Thompson of the Conservation and Collection Care Department at Cambridge University Library, and digitised in full by the Library's Cultural Heritage Imaging Laboratory, thanks to a donation by Edmund King, Emeritus Professor of Medieval History at the University of Sheffield.
